Cell.Data:
HumanId.type is a mess. First of all, they're not orthogonal. A credit card number is a type of account number. And may be a microchip number and is a type of registry. More importantly, the types of ids that are appropriate varies by context. Providers will have different types than patients than prescriptions or clinical studies or organizations or the hundresds of other things that might have human-readable ids assigned. It's not possible to come up with an exhaustive or even semi-complete list of the types of ids that could be used. And the use-cases for what id types are exposed are very much context-specific. What makes sense for patient in in-patient ids in Canada is going to be different from what's needd for outpatient patient ids in the UK, etc. The types of codes, granularity of codes, etc. will all vary.
The purpose of .type is to allow the automated application of business rules. The business rules to be applied vary. Thus the codes need to vary. Achieving interoperability accross boundaries is going to be challenging at best. I think we need to seriously look at what the use-case is for sharing of ids with types "across boundaries" and how interoperability might work. If a Canadian patient record with a type of "RCMP id" gets shared with the UK, do we really expect business rules could be applied? Probably not. It's theoretically possible that business rules could be applied on the basis of "drivers license", but even that's suspect as out-of-jurisdiction drivers license are unlikely to be relevant. The only id type likely to be useful across borders is something like "passport". (continues)
This code is also likely to be subject to abuse, carrying information best handled by other means. For example, being used to convey the type of licensing a provider has, or distinguishing a filler-issued vs. placer-issued lab id (or even primary filler vs. secondary filler). The whole concept of HumanId.type needs to be reconsidered and any sort of vocabulary binding at the international level needs to be removed.

Discussion in Committee. The list was never meant to be complete - it's an extensible binding, and you use one of these codes when appropriate. The issue is that, for a given use-case, 2/3 or more of the codes will be inappropriate. We can't bind this attribute. Best we can do is define a domain and define a code system that creators of profiles are encouraged to draw from. but we need to hide this complexity, and just say, "you can use any codes you want, but if you use these concepts, use these codes" - and then make sure that what we offer is well defined
change to two elements "use" (based on other use elements) and label per discussion on list
Unless the HumanId element has a dataAbsentReason flag, it must contain an identifier with an id (xpath: exists(@dataAbsentReason) or exists(f:identifier/f:id))

The presense of a DAR is used in several cases in the datatypes as a means of loosening the rules for what datatype properties need to be present. However, this is mixing two things. DAR is relevant when there's a use-case for knowing why an element is missing. This is a distinct use-case from choosing to allow partial or incomplete data. For example, I ight want to allow a humanId that doesn't allow unique resolution without wanting to capture "why the id isn't fully specified". We need to separate "Partial data allowed" from "reason for absent/incomplete data allowed".

Need to explain the relationship between the interpretation of a "default value" and DAR. Specifically, we need to allow for the ability to say "I don't know how many there are" and have the system not interpret that as 0.
Remove the notion of default value

It should be possible for profiles to define events. One of the principles of FHIR is to allow for a broad range of implementation. The chances that HL7 International will be willing or able to define all the possible events that will be needed by every implementation everywhere in the world in a timely fashion is slim to none. One of the fundamental flaws of v3 was poor escape valves for extensibility, but even they new there was a need for extensibility in terms of events. Support for events is already optional, so interoperability on events isn't guaranteed. The only downside of allowing 'local' definition of events is the possibility the same thing might be defined in multiple ways with multiple ids. However, practically speaking, this won't manifest to many implementers, and when it does, it's not that hard to support different ids for the same thing in different contexts. Standardization through HL7 International will always be the "desired" thing because it increases the likelihood of consistent out-of-the-box implementation, but it shouldn't be demanded. This is something that's hard to introduce later because it requires introducing "must understand" namespacing that wasn't previously necessary. Forcing a "must understand" change due to a misplaced desire to avoid a (minimal) increase in complexity is unwise.
Discussion in committee - adding events is not to be done lightly
decided to allow events to be defined in profiles (same info as in standard, along with reference to IG)

It should be possible to profile datatypes. Profiles for datatypes are likely to be encountered for: Timing (restrict to enumeration, restrict to non-enumeration, frequency only, etc.) Contact (only phone, only e-mail, only URL) Address, HumanId (full registry style vs. contact style; variations by realm) Ratio (constraints on numerator & denominator) Quantity (constraints to other dimensions, eg. Volume)
Datatypes can be extended the same as resources. Anything that's legal in the ISO types can be an extension. We don't want to have to repeatedly declare support for a set of extensions every place a type appears in every resource profile a given realm or implementer supports. If they support a particular set of behavior for a given datatype, they should be able to define that once and reference it, just as they can for a resource.
Preventing "datatype flavors" creates far more complexity than it avoids.
Can define extensions for datatypes. Can't profile data types, that's true. Discussion in committee
agred after much discussion on the list

Search parameters should be definable in profiles. We allow for implementers to define search parameters in their conformance statements, so that already means we support a variety of behavior beyond what HL7 International defines. However, it also means that the only source of "commonly defined" search parameters is HL7 International. It's not possible for an organization, a realm, the IHE or anyone else to define additional search parameters and see them implemented consistently. Conformance statements should be about defining conformance to something already defined. Conformance statements allow defining conformance against profiles already. So it wouldn't be hard to just have the search parameters as part of that.
The links on the image map on the datatypes are broken
Only in the book version - editorial - approve

The list of values for HumanId.type suggest that they are the only possible values. The binding needs to be (and was intended to be open) - either this is a content or a publishing error that needs to be fixed
The SOA section implies that REST is not SOA. Need to fix the language somehow
Need to add a note about this being a simple REST pattern and that more complex rest solutions are possible but not described or prescribed

ss:Data.Font: "The combination of the resources and the 3 supporting layers (implementation frameworks, definitional thoroughness, and conformance tooling) frees healthcare data

U.Font: so that it can easily flow to where it needs to be

ss:Data.Font: (hospital production systems, mobile clinical systems, cloud based data stores, national health repositories, research databases, etc.)

U.Font: without having to pass through format and semantic inter-conversion hurdles along the way

Cell.Data: [emphasis added] The ballot material does not include a clear statement of objectives and of criteria by which success may be judged. Is the highlighted property (which is claimed to be the case) one of the objectives? The FHIR wiki's Business Case Issue Page appears to recognize there's an unmet need for such material.
this will be taken up as a methodology question by the FHIR management and governance groups and found on the wiki

ABSENT: a clear definition of the term "resource" -- should indicate what is and what is not a resource, and how identity of resources may/may not be related to their significations. Note the frequent use of terms like "Person" in contexts which concern the structure and content of information resources (e.g. discussions of recorded information about persons) as distinct from entities to which the resources refer. Since resources are of interest only by virtue of their relation to non-resources (e.g. my infection or systolic blood pressure or ...), this issue seems relevant.

"In this specification, resources are described in a simple XML format. … In addition to the simple XML description, W3C Schema, UML models, and other definitional models are provided that may be a useful aid for system implementation."

The organization of the document may be making it unnecessarily hard for us readers to pull together your relevant descriptions. If you say "the information resource called X is a piece of XML that matches the following pattern: … and conforms to these schematron rules" that is a clear and precise definition of the term "X". If you present a similarly clear mapping of X to an interpretation domain, that is an acceptable description of its signification (the intent of your "Formal Definitions" I guess). Providing me various alternative expressions with purportedly equivalent signification (vaguely defined if at all) is not a good description of its signification because those alternatives are no less in need of definition than your canonical information resource itself. I understand (and applaud) the good intent, but there are dangers.
well, tried. Unfortunately it's not as simple as we'd like. Can be refined over time
"FHIR elements are always in the namespace http://hl7.org/fhir. This is usually specified as the default namespace on the root element."
"FHIR elements are always in the namespace http://hl7.org/fhir. This SHALL be specified as the default namespace on the root element."
No - some toolkits don't do default namespaces. Why make trouble. Whether Namespaces are default or not is transparent to nearly all tooling anyway
This would create more costs than it would avoid, and is not correct from a standards perspective
"Profile.status.code has the definition ResourceProfileStatus: "The lifecycle status of a Resource Profile". Possible values: …"

In general, doesn't FHIR need a "lifecycle model" for information resources -- related to the possible transactional operations that may apply to a resource? The specification of such a model can be more or less constraining, i.e. might describe a family of acceptable lifecycles (expressed as transition nets) for a resource or set of resources? The provided values ("draft", "testing", ...) have names that suggest their significance without pinning down their practical implication.
For example, I was unable to discover in the document where the version of the information resource specification was discussed in relation to the possible versions (if any) of an instance conforming to that resource specification. That may be discussed in the document, but I couldn't find where.

a general life cycle management pattern is defined in the RIM, but the instantiation varies between resources. No need to reproduce the general pattern in FHIR. The profile status codes are vague, as is all existing work on templates & repositories. As for versioning, see http://hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/xml.htm#version

How does this definition meet the criterion of independence set out in §1.1 ? The definition appears to link together the agent, person and organization resource specifications, i.e. I can't understand the significance of agent if I'm clueless about the other two.
Of course that's natural. The question is really "won't you please explain what 'independent' actually mean in practice?" Lifecycle. Transactionality. etc etc etc

For safe processing of medical record data the users of semantic web technologies, e.g. SPARQL; OWL; or DL Reasoners, when processing data in/from resources containing medical data in vocabulary systems based on EL+ or another intensional logic system i.e. SNOMED CT, require an understanding of where or in what resource components or model nodes the logic system is used versus where it is not used, or where it is mixed with data modeled in another logic system. In other words, for example, labelling "where it is safe to run a reasoner and where it is not." The reason this is required is that SNOMED is not just a bunch of codes that define concepts; it is an intensional logic system in which any lists of codes for terms are defined by a set of SNOMED characteristics or conditions that are necessary and sufficient to define or infer the intended use dynamically. Optional resource labelling (a.k.a. "Semantic Node Labelling" or SNL) as an expansion of existing FHIR resource tagging/labelling and coding system identification could be devised to meet this requirement; for example an optional higher level metadata boolean "IS INTENSIONAL" could be supplemented by additional lower level optional tags for "LOGIC SYSTEM"; "TERMINOLOGY SYSTEM COMPONENT/HIERARCHY" or alternative metadata. Thus FHIR would avoid having secret arbitrary knowledge about a resource implementation be required to know where it is safe to use SNOMED logic safely and reliably; similarly intensional model data would not be found in areas where it is not intended.

we believe that this is met by a combination of Coding/CodeableConcept and the mapping infrastructure and mappings provided as part of the ballot and profiles. However this work is as yet incomplete, so this issue should be revisited - particularly by implementation experience - later
Change data type "Coding" to "Concept", rename "coding" XML element within CodeableConcept to "concept"
Inconsistent naming of the data type, "Coding" is verb, whereas "CodeableConcept" is Noun. The name of data type shall be all in Noun.
Discussion in committee (Lloyd: I think "Coding" can be a noun too. It's an abbreviation of "Encoding". It represents the encoding of a single concept.)
Run out of time for formal discussion (sorry) - Coding is a noun, and it's in this sense that it's used. Can re-raise in further ballot if desired
The existing XML element "code" and "value" in Choice data type is confusing since the people typically will link "code" and "value" as one pair. Change "value" to "list" instead
Need a new name - not list though. "option"?

Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) defines a set of resources for use in exchanging information about the healthcare processes. Resources are:
Flexible - resources can also be used in other contexts, such as messaging or SOA architectures, and moved in and out of RESTful paradigms as convenient

FHIR shall include additional design to demonstrate how individual resources and aggregate resources can be efficiently used in other contexts such as messagin and SOA architecture, amd moved in and out of RESTful paradigms as convenient

As explained in 1.1- Overivew, resource must be "Flexible - resources can also be used in other contexts, such as messaging or SOA architectures, and moved in and out of RESTful paradigms as convenient". Howerver the design of Prescription resource does not enable the efficient reuse of resources in other contexts such as messaging and SOA architectures.
It is true that how data is persisted is outside FHIR concern or any exchange format design, but the design of resources and how individual resources are aggregated for exchange must be efficiet for processing on both service client and provider ends.
For more detail reasoning and comment, pls take a look at the my detail analysis at the following site
http://healthinterconnect.blogspot.sg/2012/08/the-design-of-fhir-prescription-resource.html
Discussion in committee. I'm not persauded - Lloyd to generate more comment
some additional text has been added to the implementations page, but still more is needed about mixing environments

The FHIR Specification should be split up into separate specifications for ease of version management. The core FHIR spec should just cover the information models, datatypes and extensibility/profiles. The REST FHIR spec should cover the RESTful implmenations (and there could be others here). Then each Resouce should have its own specification.
Essentially this proposes to version each part separately. I am entirely opposed

The FHIR specification is integrated. Each of its parts has dependencies on other parts. Separating into multiple specifications would result in extreme difficulty managing varying versions of the different parts. This has caused extensive grief with HL7 v3. There is very little benefit to splitting the specification and considerable benefit to implementers in keeping it as one cohesive specification that is versioned as a whole.
Consider the W3C Community Contributor License Agreement http://www.w3.org/community/about/agreements/cla/. This will cover all the requirements (copyright, and patent IP)
This is more than a license. But we should propose this to the HL7 Board. Issue adopted for further action by the FGB - to proceed in concert with the board

"Though the resources are simple and easy to understand, they are backed by a thorough, global requirements gathering and formal modeling process that ensures that the content of the resources is stable and reliable. The resource contents are mapped to solid underlying ontologies and models using computable languages (including RDF) so that the definitions and contents of the resources can be leveraged by computational analysis and conversion processes"

This statement is simply not true. The Resources and other FHIR components are expressed in UML and encoded in XML. There is no mapping to RDF and you should not assume that such a mapping would then give you a computable model (ie extensional VS intensional modelling regimes). We propose that all the information models be represented - natively - in RDF/OWL - and then the encoding can be RDF/XML. Alternately, the encoding can be "plain-old XML" but the models must be semantically based.
There's no way that we'll be calling the native representation RDF/OWL. Agree that this is not true at this time - this is an area that needs to be developed. Thank you for contributing in this area
Agree that the resourcesare not properly mapped at this time - this is an area that still needs further work, but is explicitly planned
"Every resource SHALL include a human readable narrative "
Some Resources may not be for human consumption, so this requirements should be optional
Discussion for committee. The rationale for SHALL is that you mostly do not know what the use of the resource will be in the future, and always providing a human readable description is not expensive
The supported markup for human consumption should be HTML5 expressed as well-formed XML. There should be no other restrictions.. Note that XHTML has been superseeded by HTML5
There must be restrictions. There is nothing in HTML 5 that is appropriate to use (wrong: new elements and attributes like <section> , < a media=”handheld”>, etc…)
Adopt HTML 5 and update the restriction list accordingly
"The logical id and version id of a Resource can take one of the following forms: "

There is no reason why there are such arcane restrictions on the format/syntax of the <id> element. It should be defined as a string only. "Resource Ids must be in lowercase" is arbitarily limiting (for no reason)

Actually, the only restriction is that it must be any combination of lowercase letters, digits, - and . The lowercase restriction is worth discussing. Don't want to allow unicode characters, or arbitrary length, or characters that need escaping. Is there a practical problem?
changed as part of the revisiting the identification of resources
"There is no explicit version marker in the XML"
XML Namespaces are used as unique identifiers, and hence versions of XML content.
There is no version marker for the internal version of FHIR
"The problem with this approach is that not only is the <<mixin>> stereotype not a recognised standard UML syntax"
Only use standardised concepts and techniques.
Better make the intent of this little section clearer

FHIR should simply adopt all of the XML Schema datatypes natively. This section makes some bizzare restrictions on datatypes without any justification and increases the validation burden. Update this section by adopting the XMLSchema datatypes.
These are the XML schema data types. They are defined here to remove technical dependency on the schema, but they are the same
Add description about what is being done to the Spec column including reference and fix explanation for base64Binary
There does not seem any support for an Identifier that is a single string, such as a URI. For example, SNOMED is now developuing a URI scheme for its concepts
There is support - the system is http://fhir.org/sid/uri
after much discussion on list, stuck with existing approach, but documented handling of URI identification better
"Note that a human identifier may be a system identifier"
This is in conflict with the defintion of a HumanID
added a few extra works in the documentation to make the intent clearer
There seems to a lot of redundancy here and no way to detect invalid combinations of type.code and identifier.system

What's the redundancy? Agree that invalid combinations are a problem, but this is inherent in the problem, not the solution - Lloyd: Well, we can provide guidance that says that type SHALL NOT be used to convey a concept that is an identifier.system. But that's going to make people unhappy given that real world systems mess this up so regularly.
though invalid combinations are not resolvable
FHIR should adopt common mechanisms to express names, such as vCard, FOAF. These also have RDF bindings
FOAF is not a standard nor common. vCard does not meet requirements, though the mapping is close. (Need to be clear about exactly what requirements vCard doesn't make)
changed to be more like vCard and added vCard mappings after discussion on the list
FHIR should adopt common mechanisms to express names, such as vCard, FOAF. These also have RDF bindings
FOAF is not a standard nor common. vCard does not meet requirements, though the mapping is close. (Need to be clear about exactly what requirements vCard doesn't make)
changed to be more like vCard and added vCard mappings after discussion on the list
The examples that show complex <duration> elements that can be simplifed if the duration dataype was adopted from the XML Schema datatypes. The last example would then be: <duration>P30m</duration>
There might be some benefit in using schema duration rather than FHIR duration in schdule
Simplify based on existing approach rather than use Duration type
Use of HL7 uris for other orgs artefacts

The URIs should reflect those who define/own that system. For example the "W3C URI" URI (actually IETF URI) should be defined by IETF. This is a serious issue with FHIR. It does not seem to respect the URI being an identification system that covers BOTH the system-type and the actual identifier value. For example, OIDS can be expressed as single URIs.
see #32 and removed oid and uuid - they are always URIs
The XML may be validated by schema and schemas are provided, but validation is not required in operational systems

It is preferable to include a conformance constraint like “.. SHALL validate against the Resource schema when extensions are excluded”. This will permit to assert minimum interoperability requirement.
see "XML that is exchanged must be valid against the w3c schema and Schematron" in 1.2.8. is this not enough? (extensions are valid against schema)
add to note that "run-time systems" are not required to validate against schema
Each narrative has a flag that specifies the relationship between the narrative and the structured data. This flag may have one of the following codes
This flag/attribute SHALL be a union between any or all of these possible values. At least there shall be an approach to represent extension with additional data.
Why is that necessary? What difference would it make? (outstanding issue on wiki)
Deferred pending response from balloter. Need to understand how software would behave differently with combinations of these.
look into this at the next connectathon

Each mapping has narrative id and structured data id which provide internal references (§1.2.5) to the narrative and the structured data respectively, and a flag for whether the text was generated from the data, or the data was generated from the text (by some form of retrospective processing, whether human or computer), or whether both come from an external source
The possible values provided for ‘Narrative.map.source’ are ‘text’ and ‘date’. Need to include a possible value for this scenario. 'When the text generated from an external source'.
This is an example with some xhtml formatting.

The HTML elements shall be included in the HTML namespace [Ex: instead of

]. This is to distinguish HTML elements from FHIR proprietary elements.
Make one example explicitly namespaced and add a comment about that
OIDs and UUIDs may be registered in the HL7 OID registry (http://hl7.org/oid) and should be if the content is shared or exchanged across institutional boundaries

A code may be registered in any publicly available OID register other than HL7 OID register. Why the is HL7 OID registration is encouraged? This may result in duplicate OID registration and maintenance issue.
Given that the OID registration is trivial, and that they are very rarely maintained, why not? And if they aren't, how to find them? One place is better. But it's only "should"

The purpose is to provide a single location where implementers can find the OIDs needed. The OIDs can be *issued* by any registrar. The only request is for them to be recorded in the HL7 registry. Maintenance of the information is infrequent and generally irrelevant. (It doesn't matter what the contact information or other metadata is for a code system, only that for a given code system a particular OID is used - and that should hardly ever change.
<use><!-- 0..1 code The use of this name --></use>
The HumanName.Use possible values do not include certain values like Professional /Business Name (Artist/Stage) name, etc… Are these expected to be included as an extensions?
yes, these are extremely rarely used
expected to be extensions in the rare case that they are used
The DocumentHeader.Section class does not contain an extension attribute. Can extensions be added to section class? Else the Document extension encloses extension for section?
Document extension includes extensions for sections. Design of sections to be reviewed
all extensions at the end, context by reference
The Class Profile UML diagram is not consistent with its corresponding Resource Profile XML pseudo code. Ex: the Profile Class is missing the following attributes. 1. id 2. author
id comes from parent - but parent reference is missing. Author is present

Why is the Profile.version an optional element/attribute? What is the default version number for a resource? What is the version increment convention if the initial version of the resource does/does not include a version number?

Formal versioning in FHIR is handled by metadata. This attribute is for "external" version labels determined by the profiles author. FHIR has no policy around when, how or if this version string is populated or changed. The attribute exists to support the descriptive version labels frequently used in templates and profiles. Will add additional guidance to clarify this intended usage.

The profile.version is under manual control of the profile author. It is up to the author how to make use of this attribute (note that it's not the resource version id - that changes as specified in the infrastructure)
The energy should go into v3 implementation improvements, not to another canibal in the HL7 ranks.

From Lloyd: Not persuasive - There are two ways to look at FHIR. One can look at it as a means of enhancing/fixing v3, in which case the energy spent on FHIR is doing exactly what the voter desires. Another is to look at FHIR as an alternative to v3 because there are certain fundamental implementation impediments of v3 such as complex model-driven wire format and non-backward compatible versions that cannot be changed without making v3 unrecognizable. In short, either FHIR is enhancing v3 or FHIR is necessary because v3 can't be sufficiently enhanced.

It is essential, in my opinion to establish early on that the difference between FHIR and "just another cute XML representation" is the previously stated objective to bind the FHIR resources to established Health Informatics foundations. This means, I believe, the required mappings (as discussed when FHIR was proposed) to the HL7 RIm, plus, ISO data types (or Abstract DT R2). While these are possible in the current document, there is no commitment in this "book" to require and establish such mappings. I suggest that the discussion of the FHIR Community in HL7 be extended to clearly make such a linkage
Add brief mentions in the ontologies and community section. Also, need to ensure that the methodology (on the wiki?) covers our obligations clearly
extensibility bullet - "cater for" should be either "cater to" or "allow for"

roadmap is an excellent organizing idea BUT - the contents of the bullets (the section after the bullet "title" are BADLY mixed: about half are noun phrases (like the first three in 1.1.1.1; and the others are verb phrases (like the second three in 1.1.1.1. This makes for clumsy reading. Suggest using glossary-like noun phrases for all.

I stumbled through the notes the first three times I read it trying to decide if the description was of XML elements or pseudo-XML elements. Needs an adjective (on "element" here and there to make it clear. For instance, I believe the third bullet should begin "To build a valid instance of a resource...." and if I am wrong, this is evidence of the confusion that arises from the text.
want to propose a clearer text?
If FHIR is based on and mapped to HL7 RIM and datatypes, I believe dataAbsentReason values should be mapped to one (or set) of null favors. This should either appear here or be linked to from here.
agree, though not sure where - methodology issue
bis "class base" UML diagram. This is interesting, but there is neither a caption to it nor a reference from either 1.2.3 or 1.2.4 It dangles and probably needs some annotation

The key issue for FHIR (and by extension HL7) is “what problem are we trying to solve”? There is little value in amassing technical specifications without foundational requirements statements which: • Scope and detail the problem space; • Allow comparability (across Standards); and • Can be concisely measured for fulfillment.
Requirements statements allow ready assessment of FHIR (as proposed), alongside HL7’s extant suite of Standards including v2, v3, CDA, RIM, EHR and PHR System Functional Models. Requirements statements also allow demonstration of how far we’ve come (v2 and on) and how far we have yet to go.
It is unclear if/how this project should proceed without explicit Requirements Statements that show fit, consistency and contrast with/among HL7’s existing suite of Standards. This is both prudent and fundamental.

ok, so we we should have requirements and success criteria - that's reasonable. But I do not think they belong in the specification itself; they are a governance artifact (Lloyd: I think they should be in the specification, or at least referenced from the specification. Most people coming to FHIR for the first time are going to want to understand context. And if we want people to vet the appropriateness of FHIR, hard to do so when we don't define what it's for.) - FGB adopts the tasks of describing the aspirations for FHIR, and the success criteria by which progress by which it may be assessed
FGB will describe the aspirations for FHIR, and the success criteria by which progress by which it may be assessed, and ensure that this is easily available to the users

In 2012, EHR (PHR and other) systems are being certified for record management functions. Data/record management starts at the point of origination and must be continuously (uninterruptedly) assured through each point of retention (at rest) and exchange (in motion). Data/record management encompasses:
• Lifespan: from point of origination to permanent offline archive or loss/destruction • Lifecycle, starting at origination and at each event thereafter: attestation, amendment, access/view, transmittal/disclosure, receipt, archival… • Identity: subject, participant, observer, author, co-author, organization, system • Capture, origination, source, provenance • Authorship, signature, signature binding to content • Attestation, for accuracy/completeness • Non-repudiation • Amendment, preservation of prior content, audit logs and amendment history • Retention, persistence • Non-alteration • Consents, permissions to access, consent binding to content • De-Identification • Encryption • Transmittal, disclosure, disclosure logs • Receipt, consumption • Content binding: author/system signature, consent/permissions, amendment logs
As a key reference for certification programs worldwide ISO/HL7 10781 EHR System Functional Model Release 2 specifies twenty-four (24) distinct record lifecycle events. Four (4) relate directly to exchange (transmit, output/report, disclose, receive).
If FHIR “resources” are intended as exchange only (transient) artifacts, then Requirements Statements should be scoped in consideration of applicable bullets above and the four EHRS FM lifecycle events
If FHIR “resources” are intended as Records Management (persistent) artifacts, then Requirements Statements should be scoped in full consideration of all bullets above and all EHRS FM lifecycle events

FHIR should support these processes without imposing them. For example, a resource will be available that supports capture of information about security events such as access/view, transmittal/disclosure, etc. It can be used where there is a need for such information to be exchanged or (when FHIR is used to guide persitance models) stored. FHIR as a whole cannot be certified based on the EHR functional model. However, FHIR-based solution specifications should be able to be - once the necessary set of FHIR resources is complete. FHIR should be seen as providing a tool kit from which solutions can be constructed. Solutions for simiple solutions with simple architectures are provided out of the box. Solutions for more complex environments will require additional layers of organization and specification on top. In some cases this will be done at the international level by HL7. In other cases, it will be done at a more local level, depending how consistent requirements are across jurisdictions and domains.
added illustrative mapping between EHR-FM and FHIR
If FHIR “resources” are intended to be transient, why aren’t extant interchange standards sufficient? This goes back to comparison exercise outlined in Comment 1
Refer to tutorial content - where should such information live?

Presume this is asking why we're defining REST? If so: FHIR resources may be exchanged via a variety of transport protocols such as TCPIP, MLLP, etc. However, to use REST approaches, additional guidance must be provided given the derth of standardization of RESTful interfaces.
FHIR resources can be used transiently, but are intended to be persistable. But even if they weren't persistable, it would still be worth defining for it's other advantages

Preservation of author’s signature binding to authored content is an essential requirement for virtually all primary health data/record use. Primary use includes immediate clinical intervention/care and decision making. This author/content binding requirement also extends to health data/records submitted for substantiation of claims for payment and many other uses.
In reading this FHIR specification it is unclear how author/content binding is preserved through an instance of FHIR exchange. Please clarify
Currently, the provision is sign bundles of resources, with no provision for signing individual resources. This is subject to ongoing review pending real-world experience
(Per Comment 4) If the key focus of FHIR is secondary data/record use, then we stand begging the question of whether it should be a major initiative for HL7 going forward. Needs clarity
Agree. Should it be? It might be, but way too early to commit either way
this is a matter of voting with feet. Currently, there is strong interest

Capture and management of consents/permissions for data/record access – including explicit binding to related content – is emerging as an essential requirement. In terms of this FHIR specification it is unclear how consents/permissions and their binding to content are established and preserved. Needs clarity

Both "Consent" and "DataPolicy" are expected to be resources introduced into FHIR. Where necessary/appropriate, other resources and even elements within resources will be able to link to these elements.
acknowledgement the relevance of the requirements, but this is not yet dealt with - to be resolved in the future

If FHIR is not about Records Management (full lifespan/lifecycle) and preservation of authorship and consent/permission bindings to content, how relevant it is in today’s market much less with foresight ahead 10-20 years? Needs clarity

FHIR is intended to be able to be used in a variety of environments. In some cases it will be used merely for transmission of raw data from mobile devices to some central store. In other cases it may be used for full records management. FHIR should provide the pieces to support a full life cycle approach where needed without forcing that overhead on use-cases that don't need it.

FHIR is intended to be able to be used in a variety of environments. In some cases it will be used merely for transmission of raw data from mobile devices to some central store. In other cases it may be used for full records management. FHIR should provide the pieces to support a full life cycle approach where needed without forcing that overhead on use-cases that don't need it.

FHIR Introduction: “Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) defines a set of ‘resources’ for health. These resources represent granular clinical concepts that can be exchanged in order to quickly and effectively solve problems in healthcare and related processes. The resources cover the basic elements of healthcare - patients, admissions, diagnostic reports, medications and problem lists - with their typical participants and also support a range of richer and more complex clinical models. The simple direct definitions of the resources are based on thorough requirements gathering, formal analysis and extensive cross-mapping to other relevant standards.”
What does “healthcare interoperability” mean in this context? Are we making the process (provision) of healthcare interoperable? Or are we making health/healthcare data/records interoperable? Please clarify

ss:Data.Font: Proposed wording: "Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) defines a set of ‘resources’
granular clinical concepts that can be
exchanged in order to quickly and effectively solve

problems in healthcare and related processes. The resources cover the basic elements of healthcare - patients, admissions, diagnostic reports, medications and problem lists - with their typical participants and also support a range of richer and more complex clinical models. The simple direct definitions of the resources are based on thorough requirements gathering, formal analysis and extensive cross-mapping to other relevant standards."

Cell.Data: It is stated that “resources represent granular clinical concepts” and that “these resources cover the basic elements of healthcare and related processes – patients, admissions…”. Resources related to patient and admission resources would likely include some non-clinical (e.g., demographics, finance, insurance, next of kin, guarantor). Make this explicit
well, ok, if you think that is necessary

To what does “with their typical participants” refer? Do “resources” have typical participants? Do “basic elements of healthcare” have typical participants? Do “patients, admissions, diagnostic reports, medications and problem lists” have typical participants?
loose wording. Yes,not really. I'll clean it up
Will change the word "participants" to "data elements"

Assume “fast” describes some aspect of time, velocity and/or response to priority or urgency. “Healthcare” (better yet “health”) describes the domain.
“Interoperability” describes what? What makes FHIR interoperable?
The EHR WG produced a “Coming to Terms” White Paper on Interoperability, reviewing more than 100 industry sources and defining three levels: Technical, Semantic and Process. The WG also produced the EHR Interoperability Model DSTU, with 56 relevant criteria. (CDA R2 meets 51 of 56.) How does FHIR measure up to these internal HL7 “interoperability” benchmarks?
FGB agrees that we should do this within the FHIR project team - FMB . Project team to make decisions about how

FHIR will undertake this analysis. However, given the "tool kit" aspect, this analysis can only really be peformed at the level of the RESTful "out of the box" capabilities of FHIR, not the capabilities that can be created with FHIR-based solutions. E.g. It would be possible to define an equivalent specification to CDA using FHIR. It would have characteristics that would differ from the based RESTful capabilities of FHIR. As well, a proper analysis of FHIR's interoperability capabilities will be somewhat dependent on the completion of a basic set of resources, some of which are not yet developed.
We may need to define the update behavior of the metadata
part of rework of id element
How to represent deletions of resources in feed
Need to describe obligations and error codes around create and update operations
Document explicitly that servers are allowed to reject updates because of internally defined rules about update integrity, and list particular error codes
Need to add back to the conformance resource about how creates and ids work for a system
Add a section discussing ids, distributed systems, re-allocations and how this relates to obligations on described operations (and how this relates to other identifiers)
Need to avoid imposing requirement to keep version history while still supporting versioning as much as possible

Agree - document the difference between supportng vread and full version history, and make clear how to respond with "this version is not known", and make clear that versioning is always an obligation. Atom link is version specific
Make Atom link version a specific reference
update and change other documentation accordingly
Add note about error handling only specified when HTTP spec is ambiguous in mapping to FHIR
Version Specific updates - can't implement the way this is described because location is not a request header.
what values can go in format=
allow "xml" or "json" or a full mimetype
id in all resources must be 0..1 per resource format page

fix atom schema to require summary - and check consistency between summary and text (decide whether summary

tx page refers to second tab - doesn't exist in book form!

•The XML character set is always unicode. Specifying the character encoding is optional but recommended. Any encoding that is round trip compatible with unicode is allowed.
If not specified is utf8 assumed?
Unimtended line break in bullets at 'home phone number'.
Every resource SHALL include a human readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource

While this could be desireable in some circumstances, in others it will server to interfere with pure machine to machine processing so what is the justification for making this requirement mandatory in all cases rather than on a per resource basis?

If this will be required (SHALL) then suggest adding a code to the narrative.status list for 'ignore' then the text could be empty, or 'a stock null place holder' and the sender doesn't need to do much to populate and the receiver doesn't need to do much to receive, ignore or regenerate.
Unintended line break before documents in 'the context of documents'.
Should probably be combined with the bullet below for completeness and to make the statement grading '4 cases' true.

In a single resource, this works exactly like xml:id/idref, but there is an important difference: the uniqueness and resolution scope of these id references is within the resource that contains them. If multiple resources are combined into a single piece of XML, such as an atom feed, duplicate values may occur between resources. This must be managed by applications reading the resources.
Suggest instead that globally unique ID's be required so that collisions cannot occur.

even if every xml:id is a UUID, there'll still be clashes when you view a history for a resource, or, more generally, when two versions of the same resource are floating around. So the base rule remains
Both the id and the version are URL based references - they must be literal URLs that resolve to the location of the resource.

How does '034AB16' constitute a relative url to the resource 'Patient'? Or is this just a 'logical location' akin to the logical unique id - not a location where you can expect to actually obtain a copy of the resource?
Note that absolute URLs that do not point to FHIR RESTful servers do not need to include the id in the URL, though this is good practice
Would this not result in non-unique, and non-specific, ids?
text removed due to other changes
no, because the url is still the id - it's just not portable in the same sense as if the logical id was explicit
Applications are not required to ignore unknown elements, but must declare whether they will do so in their conformance statements using the acceptUnknown element.
Doesn't this still leave processing ambiguity? Can't receivers then reject on the bases of mear existance of new elements which they aren't required to understand?
Is it really helpful to represent the range codes (<=, <, >, >=) with codes which must be escaped? Wouldn't it be more friendly to use values such as GE, GT, LT LE?
works nicely in json, object models. XML escaping should be transparent?
If the low element is missing, a dataAbsentReason flag must be provided on the Period element in this case. If the high is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.

Why is the low always known, or a missing reason required, but if the high not supplied it is assumed the period hasn't ended - may the end is simple missing? Suggest that the missing reason be supplyable or both low and high.
